services.name: AI-Powered Predictive Maintenance
services.overview: This service provides predictive maintenance capabilities for material handling equipment by leveraging real-time sensor data and machine learning algorithms. It aims to minimize unexpected downtime, reduce maintenance costs, and extend the lifespan of critical equipment. The system continuously monitors equipment performance through various sensors, analyzes the data for anomalies and patterns indicative of potential failures, and generates proactive maintenance recommendations. This allows maintenance teams to schedule repairs and replacements during planned shutdowns, avoiding costly emergency repairs and production interruptions. The service integrates seamlessly with existing maintenance management systems and provides actionable insights through a user-friendly dashboard.
problems_addressed: Unexpected equipment downtime leading to production losses
High maintenance costs associated with reactive repairs
Reduced equipment lifespan due to undetected wear and tear
core_features: Real-time Sensor Data Monitoring – Continuously collects data from various sensors (vibration, temperature, pressure, flow, etc.) installed on critical equipment.
Machine Learning-Based Failure Prediction – Employs trained ML models to analyze sensor data and predict potential equipment failures with associated confidence levels and estimated time to failure.
Predictive Maintenance Scheduling – Generates maintenance recommendations, including specific tasks, required parts, and optimal scheduling based on predicted failure timelines.
Alerting and Notification System – Provides timely alerts and notifications to maintenance personnel regarding potential equipment failures and recommended actions.
Reporting and Analytics Dashboard – Offers a comprehensive dashboard displaying equipment health, predicted failure rates, maintenance history, and cost savings analysis.
user_journeys: A maintenance manager logs into the predictive maintenance dashboard. They review the overall equipment health status, identifying a conveyor belt system flagged as 'at-risk' due to unusual vibration patterns. The system predicts a bearing failure within two weeks with 85% confidence. The manager schedules a maintenance task to replace the bearings during the next planned shutdown, avoiding an unscheduled production halt.
ai_capabilities: Regression models (e.g., Random Forest, Gradient Boosting) to predict remaining useful life (RUL) of equipment components.
Anomaly detection algorithms (e.g., Isolation Forest, One-Class SVM) to identify deviations from normal operating conditions.
Time series analysis (e.g., ARIMA, LSTM) to analyze sensor data trends and forecast future equipment performance.

Model selection: Consider fine-tuning pre-trained models or training custom models based on the availability and quality of historical maintenance data. Embeddings can be used to represent equipment types and failure modes for similarity-based predictions. Vector search is suitable for quickly identifying similar past failures.

input_data_types: Sensor data (vibration, temperature, pressure, flow, current, voltage)
Equipment maintenance history (repair dates, parts replaced, failure descriptions)
data_schema_recommendations: Equipment Table: equipment_id (INT, PRIMARY KEY), equipment_name (VARCHAR), equipment_type (VARCHAR), manufacturer (VARCHAR), model (VARCHAR), installation_date (DATE)
Sensor Data Table: sensor_data_id (INT, PRIMARY KEY), equipment_id (INT, FOREIGN KEY), timestamp (TIMESTAMP), sensor_type (VARCHAR), sensor_value (FLOAT)
Maintenance History Table: maintenance_id (INT, PRIMARY KEY), equipment_id (INT, FOREIGN KEY), maintenance_date (DATE), failure_description (TEXT), parts_replaced (TEXT)
Predictions Table: prediction_id (INT, PRIMARY KEY), equipment_id (INT, FOREIGN KEY), timestamp (TIMESTAMP), predicted_failure_date (DATE), confidence_level (FLOAT)
data_sources: Existing sensor networks (SCADA systems, IoT platforms)
data_requirements.privacy_and_compliance: Ensure compliance with data privacy regulations (e.g., GDPR, CCPA) when collecting and processing sensor data. Implement appropriate security measures to protect sensitive equipment and operational data.

required_integrations: Existing CMMS/EAM systems (e.g., SAP PM, IBM Maximo) for work order management
SCADA systems for real-time sensor data acquisition
IoT platforms (e.g., AWS IoT, Azure IoT Hub) for device connectivity and data ingestion
Email/SMS gateways for alerting and notifications
integration_plan.authentication_strategy: OAuth 2.0 or JWT for secure API authentication. Consider using Clerk or Auth0 for user management and authentication.

technical_specifications.architecture: The architecture comprises a sensor data ingestion pipeline, a data processing and storage layer, an AI model training and deployment pipeline, and a user interface. Sensor data is ingested from various sources, preprocessed, and stored in a database. ML models are trained on historical data and deployed to predict equipment failures. The UI provides access to real-time data, predictions, and maintenance recommendations.

recommended_tech_stack.frontend: Next.js 14 App Router, TailwindCSS, shadcn/ui, Vercel conventions
recommended_tech_stack.backend: Node.js / Next.js server actions / Vercel serverless functions
recommended_tech_stack.database: Planetscale / Supabase / PostgreSQL with schema notes (see data schema recommendations)
recommended_tech_stack.storage: Supabase storage / AWS S3 / Vercel Blob for storing historical sensor data and model artifacts
recommended_tech_stack.AI: OpenAI API for general text analysis of failure descriptions. Embeddings for similarity searches of past failures. Vector DB (Pinecone/Supabase vectors) to store and query embeddings.
recommended_tech_stack.APIs: REST APIs for data ingestion, model prediction, and UI interaction

API_design: /api/sensors/ingest (POST): Accepts sensor data payload with equipment_id, timestamp, sensor_type, and sensor_value. Returns 200 OK on success.
/api/predictions/equipment/{equipment_id} (GET): Retrieves predicted failure date and confidence level for a given equipment_id. Returns JSON with predicted_failure_date and confidence_level.
/api/maintenance/recommendations/{equipment_id} (GET): Retrieves maintenance recommendations for a given equipment_id. Returns JSON with recommended_actions, parts_required, and schedule.
frontend_components: Equipment Health Dashboard: Displays overall equipment health status using color-coded indicators (e.g., green for healthy, yellow for at-risk, red for critical).
Predictive Maintenance Schedule: Shows a calendar view of scheduled maintenance tasks based on predicted failures.
Equipment Details Page: Provides detailed information about individual equipment, including real-time sensor data, maintenance history, and predicted failure timelines.
Alerting and Notification Center: Displays a list of active alerts and notifications related to potential equipment failures.

deployment_instructions: Directory Structure: /frontend (Next.js app), /backend (Node.js serverless functions), /data (SQL schema, seed data), /models (trained ML models)
Environment Variables: OPENAI_API_KEY, DB_URL, SENSOR_DATA_API_KEY, CMMS_API_URL, AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID, AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY (if using AWS S3)
Vercel Deployment Steps: 1. Connect GitHub repository to Vercel. 2. Configure environment variables in Vercel project settings. 3. Enable automatic deployments on push to main branch.
Build Outputs and Runtime Settings: Next.js app will generate static HTML and serverless functions. Configure Vercel to use Node.js runtime for backend functions.

pricing_strategy: SaaS subscription tiers based on the number of monitored equipment and sensor data volume.
Usage-based pricing for API calls and data storage.
Add-ons for advanced features such as custom model training and integration with specific CMMS systems.
customer_segments: Small to medium-sized manufacturing plants with limited maintenance resources.
Large enterprises with complex material handling systems and high uptime requirements.

success_metrics: Accuracy of failure predictions (precision, recall, F1-score).
Adoption rate of the predictive maintenance schedule (number of scheduled tasks completed).
User engagement with the dashboard and alerting system (daily/monthly active users).
